Yes, there are a few programs and initiatives that help make agricultural technologies more accessible to small farmers in rural areas. Some of them are:

1. Agritech startups: There are several agritech startups that offer services and solutions to small farmers. These startups often focus on affordable technologies and provide knowledge-sharing and training programs to help farmers to adopt them.

2. Government initiatives: Some governments offer subsidies and financial aid to small farmers to invest in new technologies. For example, some countries offer low-interest loans or grants to help farmers purchase equipment, fertilizers, or improve irrigation systems.

3. Non-profit organizations: Several non-profit organizations provide training and support to small farmers to help them access new technologies. These entities may also connect farmers with other resources such as seed banks or agricultural extension services that help farmers improve their agricultural productivity.

4. Public-private partnerships: Public-private partnerships can help make technologies accessible to small farmers by bringing together government, private sector, NGOs, and academia to invest in research and development, and to make products and services more affordable.

Overall, these programs and initiatives aim to ensure that small farmers have access to technologies that can help them increase their yields, reduce their costs, and improve their livelihoods.
